title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Continuing Education Activity
content: Calcitonin gene-related peptide receptors (CGRP) receptor antagonists and monoclonal antibodies against CGRP and its receptor are medications used in the management and treatment of migraine, which is the sixth-highest cause worldwide of years lost due to disability as per the Global Burden of Disease Study (2013). This activity describes the indications, actions, and contraindications for these drugs as valuable agents in the prophylaxis and acute management of migraine and cluster headaches. This activity will highlight the mechanism of action, monitoring, adverse events, relevant interactions, and other key elements in the clinical setting as relates to the essential points needed by members of an interprofessional team managing the care of patients with migraines.
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Continuing Education Activity. Calcitonin gene-related peptide receptors (CGRP) receptor antagonists and monoclonal antibodies against CGRP and its receptor are medications used in the management and treatment of migraine, which is the sixth-highest cause worldwide of years lost due to disability as per the Global Burden of Disease Study (2013). This activity describes the indications, actions, and contraindications for these drugs as valuable agents in the prophylaxis and acute management of migraine and cluster headaches. This activity will highlight the mechanism of action, monitoring, adverse events, relevant interactions, and other key elements in the clinical setting as relates to the essential points needed by members of an interprofessional team managing the care of patients with migraines.

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Continuing Education Activity
content: Objectives: Summarize the role of RAMP1 in the formation of the CGRP receptor. Outline the currently FDA-approved drugs acting on CGRP or its receptor. Identify the most common adverse events associated with CGRP receptor antagonists. Review the importance of proper monitoring and coordination amongst interprofessional team members to improve outcomes for patients affected by migraine. Access free multiple choice questions on this topic.
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Continuing Education Activity. Objectives: Summarize the role of RAMP1 in the formation of the CGRP receptor. title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Indications
content: Calcitonin gene-related peptide is a 37-amino acid neuropeptide and a potent vasodilator produced by neurons in both the central and peripheral nervous systems. [1] The receptor for this neuro-peptide is a complex heterodimer containing a class B G-protein coupled receptor called CLR (calcitonin receptor-like receptor).
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Indications. Calcitonin gene-related peptide is a 37-amino acid neuropeptide and a potent vasodilator produced by neurons in both the central and peripheral nervous systems. [1] The receptor for this neuro-peptide is a complex heterodimer containing a class B G-protein coupled receptor called CLR (calcitonin receptor-like receptor).

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Indications
content: In the central nervous system, researchers observed that a raised level of blood and salivary levels of CGRP occur in patients with headache disorders such as migraines and cluster headaches and neuralgias such as trigeminal neuralgia, chronic paroxysmal hemicranias, and even rhinosinusitis. Levels are elevated during a migraine attack and between migraine attacks in patients with chronic migraines. Also, CGRP from exogenous infusions was shown to trigger migraine attacks. [2] Later studies showed that CGRP released in the trigeminal neurons was associated with the release of vasoactive neuropeptides and vasodilation of the cerebral vasculature, thus playing a role in the pathogenesis of migraine.
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Indications. In the central nervous system, researchers observed that a raised level of blood and salivary levels of CGRP occur in patients with headache disorders such as migraines and cluster headaches and neuralgias such as trigeminal neuralgia, chronic paroxysmal hemicranias, and even rhinosinusitis. Levels are elevated during a migraine attack and between migraine attacks in patients with chronic migraines. Also, CGRP from exogenous infusions was shown to trigger migraine attacks. [2] Later studies showed that CGRP released in the trigeminal neurons was associated with the release of vasoactive neuropeptides and vasodilation of the cerebral vasculature, thus playing a role in the pathogenesis of migraine.

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Indications
content: Migraine is a neurovascular disorder characterized by unilateral, throbbing/pounding headache accompanied by photophobia, phonophobia, nausea, vomiting, and disability and usually has a duration of around 4 to 72 hours. [3]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Indications. Migraine is a neurovascular disorder characterized by unilateral, throbbing/pounding headache accompanied by photophobia, phonophobia, nausea, vomiting, and disability and usually has a duration of around 4 to 72 hours. [3]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Indications
content: Currently, FDA-approved drugs acting on the CGRP, or its receptor, are those used in the treatment or prophylaxis of migraine. This group includes monoclonal antibodies (erenumab, eptinezumab, galcanezumab, fremanezumab) against the CGRP receptor and CGRP receptor antagonists (rimegepant and ubrogepant). In addition, atogepant and zavegepant are other receptor antagonists that have received FDA approval.
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Indications. Currently, FDA-approved drugs acting on the CGRP, or its receptor, are those used in the treatment or prophylaxis of migraine. This group includes monoclonal antibodies (erenumab, eptinezumab, galcanezumab, fremanezumab) against the CGRP receptor and CGRP receptor antagonists (rimegepant and ubrogepant). In addition, atogepant and zavegepant are other receptor antagonists that have received FDA approval.

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Indications
content: The monoclonal antibodies (erenumab, eptinezumab, galcanezumab, fremanezumab) are used for migraine prophylaxis in episodic and chronic migraine. Rimegepant and ubrogepant are used for acute treatment of migraine with or without aura. galcanezumab and fremanezumab are under development for the preventive treatment of cluster headaches.
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Indications. The monoclonal antibodies (erenumab, eptinezumab, galcanezumab, fremanezumab) are used for migraine prophylaxis in episodic and chronic migraine. Rimegepant and ubrogepant are used for acute treatment of migraine with or without aura. galcanezumab and fremanezumab are under development for the preventive treatment of cluster headaches.

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Indications
content: CGRP was also shown to have cardio-protective action in pathological conditions, as demonstrated in rodent models of different cardiovascular diseases. Studies in humans have also demonstrated that CGRP decreases afterload and increases inotropy, cardioprotective in heart failure. However, there are no drugs developed to date that take advantage of this effect on the cardiovascular system. [4]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Indications. CGRP was also shown to have cardio-protective action in pathological conditions, as demonstrated in rodent models of different cardiovascular diseases. Studies in humans have also demonstrated that CGRP decreases afterload and increases inotropy, cardioprotective in heart failure. However, there are no drugs developed to date that take advantage of this effect on the cardiovascular system. [4]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Indications
content: Similarly, newer studies find that CGRP is also involved in several other physiological/pathological phenomena, such as peripheral nerve regeneration, Alzheimer disease, vascular tone of mesenteric arteries, and pregnancy. However, no drugs have been developed which take advantage of these effects of CGRP.
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Indications. Similarly, newer studies find that CGRP is also involved in several other physiological/pathological phenomena, such as peripheral nerve regeneration, Alzheimer disease, vascular tone of mesenteric arteries, and pregnancy. However, no drugs have been developed which take advantage of these effects of CGRP.

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action
content: To understand the mechanism of action, some information on the anatomy of the CGRP receptors may prove useful. The CGRP receptor is a heteromeric receptor complex composed of three subunits:
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action. To understand the mechanism of action, some information on the anatomy of the CGRP receptors may prove useful. The CGRP receptor is a heteromeric receptor complex composed of three subunits:

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action
content: CLR (calcitonin receptor-like receptor) is a type B, G protein-coupled receptor. [5] CLR has a 55% overall identity with the calcitonin receptor for the thyroid hormone. [6] The CLR receptor (class B GPCR) contains a structured N-terminal extracellular domain (ECD) or ectodomain, a seven helix transmembrane (7-TM) domain, and an intracellular carboxyl terminus. The ECD functions as a receptor for the CGRP molecule. [7]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action. CLR (calcitonin receptor-like receptor) is a type B, G protein-coupled receptor. [5] CLR has a 55% overall identity with the calcitonin receptor for the thyroid hormone. [6] The CLR receptor (class B GPCR) contains a structured N-terminal extracellular domain (ECD) or ectodomain, a seven helix transmembrane (7-TM) domain, and an intracellular carboxyl terminus. The ECD functions as a receptor for the CGRP molecule. [7]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action
content: RAMP1 (receptor activity modifying protein 1): This is a member of the single transmembrane RAMP family and is necessary for the proper functioning of CLR. RAMP presents CLR to the plasma membrane as a mature glycoprotein. [6] Amino termini of RAMPs determine the glycosylation of CLR, which in turn correlates with the receptor phenotype. [8] The main CGRP receptor forms when CLR is delivered and modified via RAMP1. Different combinations of CLR/CTR and RAMPs (1, 2, and 3) create different glycosylation products, thus producing different receptors such as the ones for amylin and adrenomedullin. [5] CGRP may also signal via receptors other than the CLR/RAMP1 complex, such as the CLR/RAMP3 combination, which is an adrenomedullin receptor. RAMP1 may also serve as an antagonist binding site, but its role as a ligand for the binding of CGRP or its antagonists remains unclear. [8]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action. RAMP1 (receptor activity modifying protein 1): This is a member of the single transmembrane RAMP family and is necessary for the proper functioning of CLR. RAMP presents CLR to the plasma membrane as a mature glycoprotein. [6] Amino termini of RAMPs determine the glycosylation of CLR, which in turn correlates with the receptor phenotype. [8] The main CGRP receptor forms when CLR is delivered and modified via RAMP1. Different combinations of CLR/CTR and RAMPs (1, 2, and 3) create different glycosylation products, thus producing different receptors such as the ones for amylin and adrenomedullin. [5] CGRP may also signal via receptors other than the CLR/RAMP1 complex, such as the CLR/RAMP3 combination, which is an adrenomedullin receptor. RAMP1 may also serve as an antagonist binding site, but its role as a ligand for the binding of CGRP or its antagonists remains unclear. [8]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action
content: RCP (receptor component protein) is important in intracellular G protein signaling. [5]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action. RCP (receptor component protein) is important in intracellular G protein signaling. [5]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action
content: Erenumab is a human immunoglobulin G2 (IgG2) monoclonal antibody produced from Chinese hamster ovary cells. Erenumab acts by potently and competitively inhibiting the binding of CGRP to its receptor. [2]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action. Erenumab is a human immunoglobulin G2 (IgG2) monoclonal antibody produced from Chinese hamster ovary cells. Erenumab acts by potently and competitively inhibiting the binding of CGRP to its receptor. [2]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action
content: Eptinezumab is a humanized immunoglobulin G1 produced in Pichia pastoris yeast cells by recombinant DNA technology. Eptinezumab potently and selectively binds to the α and β-forms of the human CGRP ligand and prevents the activation of the CGRP receptor. It has a rapid onset of action and prolonged clinical activity. This action may be due to the rapid binding and inactivation of CGRP and slow dissociation from the peptide. [9]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action. Eptinezumab is a humanized immunoglobulin G1 produced in Pichia pastoris yeast cells by recombinant DNA technology. Eptinezumab potently and selectively binds to the α and β-forms of the human CGRP ligand and prevents the activation of the CGRP receptor. It has a rapid onset of action and prolonged clinical activity. This action may be due to the rapid binding and inactivation of CGRP and slow dissociation from the peptide. [9]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action
content: Galcanezumab is a humanized IgG4 monoclonal antibody produced in Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells by recombinant DNA technology. Galcanezumab binds to human CGRP with high affinity and prevents CGRP-induced receptor activation. Galcanezumab also inhibits capsaicin-induced vasodilation, a CGRP-induced, concentration-dependent, long-lasting relaxation of human coronary arteries. [10]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action. Galcanezumab is a humanized IgG4 monoclonal antibody produced in Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells by recombinant DNA technology. Galcanezumab binds to human CGRP with high affinity and prevents CGRP-induced receptor activation. Galcanezumab also inhibits capsaicin-induced vasodilation, a CGRP-induced, concentration-dependent, long-lasting relaxation of human coronary arteries. [10]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action
content: Fremanezumab is a fully humanized IgG2 produced by recombinant DNA technology in Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells. Fremanezumab selectively targets and binds to both the α and β isoforms of CGRP and prevents CGRP-induced receptor activation. [11]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action. Fremanezumab is a fully humanized IgG2 produced by recombinant DNA technology in Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells. Fremanezumab selectively targets and binds to both the α and β isoforms of CGRP and prevents CGRP-induced receptor activation. [11]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action
content: These monoclonal antibodies act rapidly and prevent the binding of CGRP. This receptor blockade is long-term, which leads to a reliable method of migraine prophylaxis using only a few doses of the drug per month. These drugs are degraded into small peptides and amino acids by enzymatic proteolysis before excretion, as with other monoclonal antibodies.
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action. These monoclonal antibodies act rapidly and prevent the binding of CGRP. This receptor blockade is long-term, which leads to a reliable method of migraine prophylaxis using only a few doses of the drug per month. These drugs are degraded into small peptides and amino acids by enzymatic proteolysis before excretion, as with other monoclonal antibodies.

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action
content: CGRP receptor antagonists ("gepants") are the first class of migraine-specific medication that does not have vasoconstrictive action, shows similar efficacy, has fewer adverse effects, and has a possibly longer period of activity than triptans. [7] Gepants demonstrate an extremely high affinity for CGRP receptors of human and non-human primates, preventing in this way the interaction between CGRP and its receptor. [12] The structured N-terminal extracellular (ECD) domain of CLR serves as a binding site for gepants, thus providing its fast-acting antagonistic action. The currently FDA-approved gepants are rimegepant and ubrogepant.
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Mechanism of Action. CGRP receptor antagonists ("gepants") are the first class of migraine-specific medication that does not have vasoconstrictive action, shows similar efficacy, has fewer adverse effects, and has a possibly longer period of activity than triptans. [7] Gepants demonstrate an extremely high affinity for CGRP receptors of human and non-human primates, preventing in this way the interaction between CGRP and its receptor. [12] The structured N-terminal extracellular (ECD) domain of CLR serves as a binding site for gepants, thus providing its fast-acting antagonistic action. The currently FDA-approved gepants are rimegepant and ubrogepant.

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Administration
content: The first four drugs listed are monoclonal antibodies used in the prophylaxis of chronic and episodic migraine.
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Administration. The first four drugs listed are monoclonal antibodies used in the prophylaxis of chronic and episodic migraine.

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Administration
content: Erenumab is a self-administrable subcutaneous injection. The recommended dosage is 70 mg subcutaneously once or twice a month in the abdomen, thigh, or upper arm. Alternatively, the dosage of 140 mg may be administered once a month. [13]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Administration. Erenumab is a self-administrable subcutaneous injection. The recommended dosage is 70 mg subcutaneously once or twice a month in the abdomen, thigh, or upper arm. Alternatively, the dosage of 140 mg may be administered once a month. [13]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Administration
content: Eptinezumab The recommended dosage is 100 mg of eptinezumab, administered as an intravenous infusion after dilution in 100 mL of 0.9% sodium chloride. Infusion is done over approximately 30 minutes every three months. Some patients could potentially benefit from a dosage of 300 mg. [9]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Administration. Eptinezumab The recommended dosage is 100 mg of eptinezumab, administered as an intravenous infusion after dilution in 100 mL of 0.9% sodium chloride. Infusion is done over approximately 30 minutes every three months. Some patients could potentially benefit from a dosage of 300 mg. [9]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Administration
content: Galcanezumab is administered as a subcutaneous injection. A loading dosage of 240 mg (administered as two consecutive injections of 120 mg each), followed by monthly doses of 120 mg, is recommended. Subcutaneous injection is administered in the abdomen, thigh, back of the upper arm, or buttocks. [10]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Administration. Galcanezumab is administered as a subcutaneous injection. A loading dosage of 240 mg (administered as two consecutive injections of 120 mg each), followed by monthly doses of 120 mg, is recommended. Subcutaneous injection is administered in the abdomen, thigh, back of the upper arm, or buttocks. [10]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Administration
content: Fremanezumab is administered as a subcutaneous injection. The recommended dose is 225 mg monthly or 675 mg every three months, administered as three consecutive injections of 225 mg each. Subcutaneous injection is administered in the abdomen, thigh, back of the upper arm, or buttocks. This drug provides effective prophylaxis against episodic and chronic migraines by reducing the mean number of migraine attacks per month and improvement in the mean monthly Migraine Physical Function Impact Diary (MPFID). [11]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Administration. Fremanezumab is administered as a subcutaneous injection. The recommended dose is 225 mg monthly or 675 mg every three months, administered as three consecutive injections of 225 mg each. Subcutaneous injection is administered in the abdomen, thigh, back of the upper arm, or buttocks. This drug provides effective prophylaxis against episodic and chronic migraines by reducing the mean number of migraine attacks per month and improvement in the mean monthly Migraine Physical Function Impact Diary (MPFID). [11]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Administration
content: Rimegepant is given for the acute treatment of migraine with or without aura. Rimegepant is administered as an orally disintegrating tablet containing 75mg of rimegepant-free base orally/sublingually. Dosage should not exceed 75 mg in a 24-hour period. [14] The safety of treating more than 15 migraines in 30 days has not been established. The current commercially available tablet disintegrates in saliva so that patients can swallow it without additional liquid. [15]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Administration. Rimegepant is given for the acute treatment of migraine with or without aura. Rimegepant is administered as an orally disintegrating tablet containing 75mg of rimegepant-free base orally/sublingually. Dosage should not exceed 75 mg in a 24-hour period. [14] The safety of treating more than 15 migraines in 30 days has not been established. The current commercially available tablet disintegrates in saliva so that patients can swallow it without additional liquid. [15]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Administration
content: Ubrogepant is given orally at a dosage of 50 mg or 100 mg. 2 hours after the initial dose, a second dose may be taken if necessary. The dose should not exceed 200 mg in 24 hours. Treating any more than eight migraine episodes in 30 days is not recommended, as its safety has not yet been established. Like rimegepant, ubrogepant is for the acute treatment of migraine with or without aura. [16] Atogepant is given orally for the prevention of episodic or chronic migraines at doses of 10 mg, 30 mg, or 60 mg daily, with or without food. Zavegepant is given intranasally at 10 mg per spray once daily.
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Administration. Ubrogepant is given orally at a dosage of 50 mg or 100 mg. 2 hours after the initial dose, a second dose may be taken if necessary. The dose should not exceed 200 mg in 24 hours. Treating any more than eight migraine episodes in 30 days is not recommended, as its safety has not yet been established. Like rimegepant, ubrogepant is for the acute treatment of migraine with or without aura. [16] Atogepant is given orally for the prevention of episodic or chronic migraines at doses of 10 mg, 30 mg, or 60 mg daily, with or without food. Zavegepant is given intranasally at 10 mg per spray once daily.

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects
content: Erenumab : The adverse effects reported during the clinical studies of erenumab were injection site reactions such as injection site pain, erythema, and pruritus. There were also reports of constipation, cramps, and muscle spasms. Renal or hepatic impairment is not expected to affect the pharmacokinetics of erenumab. However, sufficient studies have not been conducted to establish the same. [13]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects. Erenumab : The adverse effects reported during the clinical studies of erenumab were injection site reactions such as injection site pain, erythema, and pruritus. There were also reports of constipation, cramps, and muscle spasms. Renal or hepatic impairment is not expected to affect the pharmacokinetics of erenumab. However, sufficient studies have not been conducted to establish the same. [13]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects
content: Eptinezumab : The adverse effects reported during the clinical studies include nasopharyngitis, angioedema, urticaria, facial flushing, and rash. Hypersensitivity reactions may also occur days after administration and may be prolonged. If a serious hypersensitivity reaction occurs, discontinue the administration of eptinezumab and initiate appropriate therapy. [9]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects. Eptinezumab : The adverse effects reported during the clinical studies include nasopharyngitis, angioedema, urticaria, facial flushing, and rash. Hypersensitivity reactions may also occur days after administration and may be prolonged. If a serious hypersensitivity reaction occurs, discontinue the administration of eptinezumab and initiate appropriate therapy. [9]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects
content: Galcanezumab, fremanezumab: The adverse effects reported during the clinical studies of these drugs were injection site reactions such as injection site pain, erythema, and pruritus. Hypersensitivity reactions may also occur days after administration and may be prolonged. If a serious hypersensitivity reaction occurs, discontinue the administration of these drugs and initiate appropriate therapy. [10] [11]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects. Galcanezumab, fremanezumab: The adverse effects reported during the clinical studies of these drugs were injection site reactions such as injection site pain, erythema, and pruritus. Hypersensitivity reactions may also occur days after administration and may be prolonged. If a serious hypersensitivity reaction occurs, discontinue the administration of these drugs and initiate appropriate therapy. [10] [11]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects
content: Rimegepant : The adverse effects reported during the clinical studies of rimegepant include nausea and rarely hypersensitivity reactions (less than 1%). Severe hypersensitivity reactions may also occur with symptoms such as dyspnea and rash. In such cases, the drug should be discontinued, and appropriate therapy should be given. Hypersensitivity reactions may occur even days after administration. [15]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects. Rimegepant : The adverse effects reported during the clinical studies of rimegepant include nausea and rarely hypersensitivity reactions (less than 1%). Severe hypersensitivity reactions may also occur with symptoms such as dyspnea and rash. In such cases, the drug should be discontinued, and appropriate therapy should be given. Hypersensitivity reactions may occur even days after administration. [15]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects
content: Ubrogepant : The adverse effects reported during the clinical studies of ubrogepant were sedation, somnolence, and dryness of the mouth. There was an increased incidence of these adverse effects when the dosage increased from 50 mg to 100 mg.
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects. Ubrogepant : The adverse effects reported during the clinical studies of ubrogepant were sedation, somnolence, and dryness of the mouth. There was an increased incidence of these adverse effects when the dosage increased from 50 mg to 100 mg.

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects
content: Dose adjustment is not recommended for patients with mild or moderate hepatic impairment. For patients with severe hepatic impairment, the recommendation is for dose adjustment. Dose adjustment is recommended for patients with severe renal impairment. [16]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects. Dose adjustment is not recommended for patients with mild or moderate hepatic impairment. For patients with severe hepatic impairment, the recommendation is for dose adjustment. Dose adjustment is recommended for patients with severe renal impairment. [16]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects
content: Atogepant: The adverse effects reported during the clinical studies of atogepant include constipation, nausea, fatigue, weight loss, and decreased appetite. No dosage adjustment is needed for patients with mild to moderate renal impairment. It is dosed at 10 mg daily in patients with severe and end-stage renal disease.
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects. Atogepant: The adverse effects reported during the clinical studies of atogepant include constipation, nausea, fatigue, weight loss, and decreased appetite. No dosage adjustment is needed for patients with mild to moderate renal impairment. It is dosed at 10 mg daily in patients with severe and end-stage renal disease.

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects
content: Zavegepant: The adverse effects reported during clinical studies of zavegepant include taste disorder, nausea, nasal discomfort, and vomiting. No dosage adjustment is needed for patients with creatinine clearance of 30 ml/min or more or with moderate hepatic impairment. It is not to be used in severe renal or hepatic disease.
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects. Zavegepant: The adverse effects reported during clinical studies of zavegepant include taste disorder, nausea, nasal discomfort, and vomiting. No dosage adjustment is needed for patients with creatinine clearance of 30 ml/min or more or with moderate hepatic impairment. It is not to be used in severe renal or hepatic disease.

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects
content: However, the data provided for all these drugs may not correspond accurately to the clinical incidence of these adverse effects. Therefore, further studies and proper clinical evaluation are necessary to predict the incidence of adverse effects properly.
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects. However, the data provided for all these drugs may not correspond accurately to the clinical incidence of these adverse effects. Therefore, further studies and proper clinical evaluation are necessary to predict the incidence of adverse effects properly.

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects
content: There is no adequate data on the developmental risk associated with the use of these drugs in pregnant women, as well as their presence in human milk, the effects on milk production, or their effects on the breastfed infant. Safety and effectiveness in pediatric patients have also not been established.
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects. There is no adequate data on the developmental risk associated with the use of these drugs in pregnant women, as well as their presence in human milk, the effects on milk production, or their effects on the breastfed infant. Safety and effectiveness in pediatric patients have also not been established.

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects
content: Clinical studies of the drugs mentioned above did not include sufficient numbers of patients aged 65 and over to determine whether this cohort responds differently from younger patients. In general, dose selection for an elderly patient should start at the low end of the dosing range. Extra caution is necessary for those patients with decreased cardiac, hepatic, or renal function.
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Adverse Effects. Clinical studies of the drugs mentioned above did not include sufficient numbers of patients aged 65 and over to determine whether this cohort responds differently from younger patients. In general, dose selection for an elderly patient should start at the low end of the dosing range. Extra caution is necessary for those patients with decreased cardiac, hepatic, or renal function.

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Contraindications
content: Erenumab : The only contraindication for the use of erenumab is hypersensitivity to drugs or excipients. The current commercially available form of erenumab makes use of substances such as latex. Allergic history to such substances should also be obtained before administration. [13] Eptinezumab, galcanezumab, fremanezumab: These drugs are contraindicated in patients with serious hypersensitivity to these or any of their excipients. [9] [10] [11]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Contraindications. Erenumab : The only contraindication for the use of erenumab is hypersensitivity to drugs or excipients. The current commercially available form of erenumab makes use of substances such as latex. Allergic history to such substances should also be obtained before administration. [13] Eptinezumab, galcanezumab, fremanezumab: These drugs are contraindicated in patients with serious hypersensitivity to these or any of their excipients. [9] [10] [11]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Contraindications
content: Studies have also shown the development of anti-drug antibodies (ADAs) against erenumab, eptinezumab, galcanezumab, and fremanezumab, with the highest prevalence of the same being in the case of eptinezumab. This reaction may also reduce the efficacy of these drugs in the long term. Rimegepant : The contraindications for use of rimegepant include, History of hypersensitivity to rimegepant, especially delayed serious hypersensitivity reactions. In patients with severe hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh C), the plasma concentrations of rimegepant were significantly higher; thus, the use of rimegepant in such cases should be avoided. Avoid the use of rimegepant in patients with end-stage renal disease (CLcr < 15 mL/min). Avoid concomitant administration with potent CYP3A4 inhibitors. Avoid concomitant administration as well as a second dose of rimegepant within 48 hours if the patient is on moderate CYP3A4 inhibitors. Avoid concomitant administration with P-gp or BCRP Inhibitors. [15]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Contraindications. Studies have also shown the development of anti-drug antibodies (ADAs) against erenumab, eptinezumab, galcanezumab, and fremanezumab, with the highest prevalence of the same being in the case of eptinezumab. This reaction may also reduce the efficacy of these drugs in the long term. Rimegepant : The contraindications for use of rimegepant include, History of hypersensitivity to rimegepant, especially delayed serious hypersensitivity reactions. In patients with severe hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh C), the plasma concentrations of rimegepant were significantly higher; thus, the use of rimegepant in such cases should be avoided. Avoid the use of rimegepant in patients with end-stage renal disease (CLcr < 15 mL/min). Avoid concomitant administration with potent CYP3A4 inhibitors. Avoid concomitant administration as well as a second dose of rimegepant within 48 hours if the patient is on moderate CYP3A4 inhibitors. Avoid concomitant administration with P-gp or BCRP Inhibitors. [15]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Contraindications
content: Ubrogepant : The contraindications for the use of ubrogepant include,
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Contraindications. Ubrogepant : The contraindications for the use of ubrogepant include,

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Contraindications
content: Co-administration of ubrogepant with a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor is contraindicated. If the patient is on moderate CYP3A4 inhibitors such as ciprofloxacin, cyclosporine, and grapefruit juice, an initial dose of 50mg may be taken. But avoid the use of the second 50 mg dose within 24 hours. A loss of ubrogepant exposure, and thus efficacy, is expected in patients taking strong CYP3A4 inducers such as rifampin, barbiturates, and phenytoin. So, avoid concomitant use. If ubrogepant and moderate or weak CYP3A4 inducers are given concomitantly, dose adjustment is recommended. Ubrogepant acts as a substrate of P-gp and BCRP efflux transporters, but clinical drug interaction studies with inhibitors of only P-gp and/or BCRP (such as carvedilol and quinidine) were not conducted. Therefore, dose adjustment is recommended when administering these concomitantly. Avoid the use of ubrogepant in end-stage renal disease (CLcr <15 mL/min). [16]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Contraindications. Co-administration of ubrogepant with a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor is contraindicated. If the patient is on moderate CYP3A4 inhibitors such as ciprofloxacin, cyclosporine, and grapefruit juice, an initial dose of 50mg may be taken. But avoid the use of the second 50 mg dose within 24 hours. A loss of ubrogepant exposure, and thus efficacy, is expected in patients taking strong CYP3A4 inducers such as rifampin, barbiturates, and phenytoin. So, avoid concomitant use. If ubrogepant and moderate or weak CYP3A4 inducers are given concomitantly, dose adjustment is recommended. Ubrogepant acts as a substrate of P-gp and BCRP efflux transporters, but clinical drug interaction studies with inhibitors of only P-gp and/or BCRP (such as carvedilol and quinidine) were not conducted. Therefore, dose adjustment is recommended when administering these concomitantly. Avoid the use of ubrogepant in end-stage renal disease (CLcr <15 mL/min). [16]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Monitoring
content: Currently, there are no guidelines in place for monitoring CGRP receptor-acting drugs. However, the general monitoring of responsiveness to monoclonal antibodies (erenumab, eptinezumab, galcanezumab, and fremanezumab) against the CGRP receptor is by periodic assessment of changes in mean Monthly Migraine Days (MMD) or monthly Migraine Physical Function Impact Diary (MPFID) activity scores. Changes in these values usually occur 3 to 4 months after starting the drug.
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Monitoring. Currently, there are no guidelines in place for monitoring CGRP receptor-acting drugs. However, the general monitoring of responsiveness to monoclonal antibodies (erenumab, eptinezumab, galcanezumab, and fremanezumab) against the CGRP receptor is by periodic assessment of changes in mean Monthly Migraine Days (MMD) or monthly Migraine Physical Function Impact Diary (MPFID) activity scores. Changes in these values usually occur 3 to 4 months after starting the drug.

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Monitoring
content: In the case of gepants, the drug's effect can be monitored by the reduction in pain 2 hours post-dose and freedom from the patient's most bothersome symptom (which may include photophobia, nausea, phonophobia). [15] [16] Several co-morbidities may also arise in patients over time, and timely modification or discontinuation of these drugs should follow accordingly.
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Monitoring. In the case of gepants, the drug's effect can be monitored by the reduction in pain 2 hours post-dose and freedom from the patient's most bothersome symptom (which may include photophobia, nausea, phonophobia). [15] [16] Several co-morbidities may also arise in patients over time, and timely modification or discontinuation of these drugs should follow accordingly.

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Toxicity
content: There is limited clinical experience with drugs acting on CGRP or its receptor. However, treatment should include general supportive measures, including monitoring of the vital signs and observation of the general clinical status. There is no specific antidote for the toxicity of erenumab, eptinezumab, galcanezumab, fremanezumab, rimegepant or, ubrogepant. [13] [9] [10] [11] [15] [16] For rimegepant, dialysis is unlikely to remove rimegepant significantly due to its high serum protein binding. [15] Since the half-life of ubrogepant elimination is about 5 to 7 hours, patient monitoring after ubrogepant overdose should continue while symptoms or signs persist or for a minimum of 24 hours. [16]
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Toxicity. There is limited clinical experience with drugs acting on CGRP or its receptor. However, treatment should include general supportive measures, including monitoring of the vital signs and observation of the general clinical status. There is no specific antidote for the toxicity of erenumab, eptinezumab, galcanezumab, fremanezumab, rimegepant or, ubrogepant. [13] [9] [10] [11] [15] [16] For rimegepant, dialysis is unlikely to remove rimegepant significantly due to its high serum protein binding. [15] Since the half-life of ubrogepant elimination is about 5 to 7 hours, patient monitoring after ubrogepant overdose should continue while symptoms or signs persist or for a minimum of 24 hours. [16]

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes
content: Since the studies regarding CGRP and its receptor, physiology, and pharmacology were conducted relatively recently, there is much unknown about it. The new drugs acting on the CGRP receptor have greater efficacy and advantages over the drugs currently used for the treatment of migraines, which may lead to the widespread use of these new drugs. However, professionals within the field of internal medicine and neurology have to take care while prescribing these drugs and properly inform patients about the potential side effects of these medications. Watching for adverse effects reported in previous studies and preparing for those that have not yet been described is also vital.
contents: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes. Since the studies regarding CGRP and its receptor, physiology, and pharmacology were conducted relatively recently, there is much unknown about it. The new drugs acting on the CGRP receptor have greater efficacy and advantages over the drugs currently used for the treatment of migraines, which may lead to the widespread use of these new drugs. However, professionals within the field of internal medicine and neurology have to take care while prescribing these drugs and properly inform patients about the potential side effects of these medications. Watching for adverse effects reported in previous studies and preparing for those that have not yet been described is also vital.

title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes
content: Drug interactions and comorbidities also affect the dosage of gepants, so they should also undergo periodic assessment; this requires proper coordination between professionals in different specialties. In the case of mAbs such as erenumab, patient education by health providers is necessary for patient compliance. These medications need a prolonged time before any significant relief can be appreciated. The pharmacist will also need to perform medication reconciliation to address drug interactions and verify all dosing is appropriate.

In the case of mAbs such as erenumab, patient education by health providers is necessary for patient compliance. title: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes
content: Finally, due to the debilitating nature of migraines, counselors, psychiatrists, neurologists, and other healthcare staff should all work together to ensure proper patient care. This interprofessional team support can help ensure appropriate medication usage, provide proper instructions to patients and/or caregivers, monitor treatment response, and care for the mental welfare of the patient and their family members. [Level 5]
